awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A Technology to Tag, Track, and Publish Proprietary Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of software technology to safeguard the purchase and distribution of proprietary data. Many industries face problems associated with data purchasing and usage, theft and re-distribution, and security and privacy. The proposed technology is designed to meet these challenges by securing data, tracking its movement, and then publishing a use receipt to a distributed ledger once it reaches its destination. The software tags individual data packets so they can be tracked among multiple transactions, providing visibility throughout a specific data-use value chain. This method provides a level of security and control, ensuring data delivery only to certified recipients.  The technology has applications in industries with challenges in data visibility and redistribution, such as financial services, healthcare, scientific data, and entertainment.

This I-Corps project explores translation of a distributed ledger technology offering the potential to prevent redistribution of proprietary data in a variety of contexts while providing a blockchain-based record for transactions between data producers and consumers. The proposed technology offers a distributed ledger for use among multiple players in a transaction. A secure, immutable system for storing proprietary data on the blockchain must be developed, as well as the ability to provide both permission-only access to the data and a trusted receipt.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our project focused on the market potential of a new software technology that can track and trace valuable, proprietary data. I-Corps enabled the project team to understand and respond to potential opportunities for this technology within three beachhead markets, including finance, entertainment, and artificial intelligence. By learning how to conduct customer discovery, with guidance from program coaches, the project team conducted 125 interviews during the 7-week training experience. I-Corps complemented the team's industry experience by enabling us to understand market segments and therefore what it means to achieve product-market fit, influencing technical development and significantly improving the likelihood of commercialization.

Based on the feedback we received from potential customers during the 7-week program, we arrived at a "go" decision to continue customer discovery and further develop our technology to improve product-market fit. We also established a new company, "TradeX", which we re-branded as "Tractiv", with the project EL and TL serving as the company CEO and CTO, respectively, and we have received substantial seed funding in support of our efforts. Since completing the I-Corps program we have conducted customer discovery interviews with approximately 350 additional individuals and have undertaken three pilots with potential beachhead customers in the financial industry to learn about and address specific problems related to data distribution and awareness. Through these pilots, we have further improved the performance of our technology but have also learned that the software is best positioned to distribute large amounts of data externally while tracking usage for compliance or security purposes. We have also learned that deployment through our APIs is the most straightforward implementation method for the data owner.

While the project's track and trace value proposition remains of interest to potential customers in the financial industry, we continue to explore promising use cases in other market segments, especially in entertainment and artificial intelligence, in hopes of achieving commercialization. Specifically, we learned through customer discovery that movie and television studios have a significant interest in securing valuable data during the program production process. From these interviews, we have been able to undertake a pilot with a large movie production company which has similarly influenced our technology development activities in support of this relationship. It is our hope that this relationship will result in commercialization and be an exemplar for other production companies interested in data security. We have also learned that AI may also represent a promising market segment in which to achieve product-market fit. Specifically, we believe we can solve for vulnerabilities relating to the identification of "deep fakes" by providing source attribution to proprietary Large Language Models (LLMs).


Last Modified: 09/16/2023
Modified by: Christopher S Hayter
